msDesc.head: Composite manuscript with ars dictaminis, astronomical and meteorological texts, medical recipes, and English poetry

support.p: Part 1 consists of parchment leaves, except for one paper leaf (f. 18) and a paper volvelle (f. 25v); Parts 2-6 consist of paper leaves.

foliation.note: Numbering in pencil in the upper right-hand corners of the rectos. '16' omitted.
This foliation sequence is followed in this catalogue record.

foliation.p: 17th-century foliation for Parts 2-6, supplemented by a modern foliator:
foliation.note: Numbering in brown ink in the upper right-hand corners of the rectos (supplemented by a modern foliator with pencil: see ff. 2:29a, 2:61a, 2:77a, 2:149a, 2:149b, 2:152a). '70' omitted.
This foliation sequence is followed in this catalogue record.

Several blank, unfoliated stubs have been photographed and are displayed here as ff. 2:[36a] and 2:[49a] (but are not included in the count of leaves in Extent, nor in the foliation statement above). Folio 2:[126a] is a blank, unfoliated leaf.
Numbering in dark ink (Roman numerals) at the center of the upper margins of the rectos.
This foliation is not followed in this catalogue record.

p.formula: 112+1-1 (1 leaf added before 1st, 12th missing) 220+2 (bifolium inserted between 10th and 11th) | 3-68 78-1 (12th excised) 88 98-3 (6th-8th excised) | 10-118 128-1 (8th missing) 136-1 (3rd missing) 148-2 (1st-2nd missing) | 1514-4 (1st-3rd and 14th missing) | [The collation for ff. 92-166 has not been established] 168 | 17eighteen | 18four

binding.p: 18th- or 19th-century half white vellum binding with purple paper over pasteboards; the separate alpha-numerical elements of the manscript's classmark are printed on three paper labels on the spine: O, 7, 20.

provenance.p: One of the manuscripts of Thomas Gale (1635/6-1702) Gale, Thomas, 1672-1744, dean of York, antiquary and fellow of Trinity College Cambridge.
One of the manuscripts of Roger Gale (1672-1744) Gale, Roger, 1672-1744, antiquary and scholar, son of Thomas Gale. Inherited from his father.

history.acquisition: Donated to Trinity College by Thomas GaleGale, Thomas, son of Roger Gale (1672-1744), in 1738. The alpha-numerical elements of its current classmark O.7.20 are printed separately on three labels pasted on the spine; its current classmark can also be found written on the inside of the front cover (O.7.20), together with the College's printed ex libris featuring its armorial coat of arms, motto (Virtus Vera Nobilitas) and name (Coll: Trin: Cant:) engraved by William Stephens, fl. c. 1740-c. 1760 (W. Stephens sculp.); its previous classmarks written on f. 1r: L.8. and 399.

recordHist.source: This catalogue entry draws on M.R. James, Western Manuscripts in the Library of Trinity College, Cambridge: A Descriptive Catalogue, Vol. 3 (1902); and Linne R. Mooney, Manuscripts in the Library of Trinity College, Cambridge, The Index of Middle English Prose, Handlist XI (Woodbridge: Brewer, 1995).

availability.p: Visitors to Trinity College who wish to consult Special Collections material are required to apply to the Library in advance of their visit. For information on eligibility and admission procedures see: Trinity College: Information for Readers.

monogr.title: The Western Manuscripts in the Library of Trinity College, Cambridge: A Descriptive Catalogue
Manuscripts in the Library of Trinity College, Cambridge
Uroscopy in Middle English: A Guide to the Texts and Manuscripts

series.title: Studies in medieval and renaissance history

msIdentifier.idno: Cambridge, Trinity College, MS O.7.20, ff. 1:1, 1:7-1:8, 1:13-1:15, 1:17-1:36

msContents.textLang: Latin texts but featuring some Middle English

msItem.title: Astronomical diagram showing the motion of the Sun
msItem.note: A circular diagram consisting of concentric circles in brown ink with a red circle representing the sun on the third circle. The diagram is accompanied by inscrptions that read: Cancer, Augem eccentrici, Aries, longitudo media, Oppositum augis, Medius motus, and Verus motus.

msItem.title: Treatise on epistolary formulae
msItem.incipit: 1:2r vt patet in hoc exemplo dictasti scripsisti fecisti voluisti
msItem.explicit: 1:6v et post nebulam dat serenum
msItem.finalRubric: 1:6v Explicit. Constat Johanni Wylkes [? Wylles] in artibus magistro
msItem.note: The treatise concerns sections on salutations to different family members (Salutaciones ad patrem matrem auunculum et huius), types of petitions (peticiones), references to received letters (Recipimus litteras vestras), and other aspects of letter writing.

msItem.title: A riddle (with solutions)
msItem.incipit: 1:6v Sum quod eram id est virgo . nec eram quod sum id est mater . nunc dicor vtrumque virgo et mater . Est quod erat deus . quod adem nec erat homo . nunc regnat vtroque deus et homo

msItem.title: Metereological treatise on rainbows and halos (fragment)
msItem.incipit: 1:7r et significat tempus sincerum
msItem.explicit: 1:7v Postea
msItem.note: The text features a circular diagram on f. 1:7v with the words Sol and Halo written in it.

msItem.title: Florilegium of moral and theological saying (fragment)
msItem.incipit: 1:8r -timum est maiorum vestigia sequi Si tege praecesserint
msItem.explicit: 1:8v Uirtus et honestis rebus propitia est
msItem.note: The text begins mid-sentence in quotations that begin with the letter O, covers those beginning with the letters P-T, and ends in the section with the letter U.

msItem.title: Tract on the four senses of scripture (? Gloss on Peter Riga's Aurora)
msItem.incipit: 1:9v [E]st autem historia quasi quedam testis temporum . Lux veritatis . Magistra vite . Vita mermorie . Nuncia Vetustatis
msItem.explicit: 1:10r quandoque a facto vt interfectio golie a david significat interfectionem diaboli a Christo
msItem.note: This text also serves as an introduction to Peter Riga's Aurora; see RenÃ© Antoine Gauthier, 'Notes sur Siger de Brabant, II. Siger en 1272â1275; Aubry de Reims et la scission des Normands'. Revue des sciences philosophiques et thÃ©ologiques, 68:1 (1984), 3-49

msItem.title: Tract on the Sabbath's Day
msItem.incipit: 1:10v Sabbato celebratur de beata maria virgine et Quare in septima feria de beate marie virgine et quo inicium habuit
msItem.explicit: 1:11r Quinta racio est vt (?) festiuius agatur in die qua deus ab omni opere requieuit

msItem.title: Note on the four senses of scriptural interpretation
msItem.incipit: 1:11r Nota quod Sacre scripture est 3x sensus: scilicet Historicus . Tropoligicus . Allegoricus . et Anogogicus
msItem.note: Full transcription.

msItem.title: Note on the four senses of scriptural interpretation
msItem.author: John (? Cassian) [attributed]
msItem.incipit: 1:11r John - Historice . significat ciuitatem terrestrem - Tropologice . Animam fidelem - Allegorice . Ecclesiam militatem - Anogogice . Ecclesiam triumphantem
msItem.note: Full transcription.

msItem.title: The two sons of Abraham as a metaphor for the historical and spiritual senses of scripture
msItem.incipit: 1:11r Abraham duos filios habuit vnum de ancilla tr. Hic vnus sensus est quem littera pretendit Et alius est sensus quem scriba intendit vt patet in textura quod per allego aliam dicitur
msItem.note: Full tarnscription.

msItem.title: List of cardinal and ordinal numbers, and numeral adjectives
msItem.incipit: 1:11v Vnus / Duo / Tres
msItem.explicit: 1:12v Millesies / Millenus / Millenariu[s]

msItem.title: Memorandum
msItem.incipit: 1:12r Richard B[e]v[e]ll off graynd borndon Ã¾e x day off Septemb[er] [...]
msItem.note: Full transcription attemped. Added in the lower margin by a (?) 16th-century hand.

msItem.title: Memorandum
msItem.incipit: 1:12v Hary Ã¾e ffete Ã¾e s[...]th [?at] Clyffords [...]
msItem.note: Full transcription attemped. Added in the lower margin by a (?) 16th-century hand.

msItem.title: Astronomical treatise (fragment)
msItem.incipit: 1:13r -bus temporibus [...] equales angulos super aliquo centro fixo
msItem.explicit: 1:15v Notandum est 2o quod epi-

msItem.title: Introduction to the Secretum Secretorum (fragment)
msItem.author: Roger Bacon
msItem.explicit: 1:17r meam . Sed queratur in libris Astronomie et maxime in libro albumasar qui vocatur introductorius in iudicia astronomie. Et cum in locis certis istius libri in quibus hec necessaria sunt multa posui vtiia et praemittitur figura signorum et [sic] et subsequentur ad emdenciam - deo gracias
msItem.finalRubric: 1:17r Expliciunt 3.a capitula de Secretus secretorum Aristotelis
msItem.note: Full transcription. For the corresponding text, see Opera hactenus inedita Rogeri Baconi Fasc. V: Secretum Secretorum cum Glossis et Notulis. Tractatus Brevis et Utilis ad Declarandum Quedam Obscure Dicta Fratris Rogeri, ed. Robert Steele (Oxford: Clarendon, 1920), p. 23.

msItem.title: Astrological note on fortunate and unfortunate positions of the signs of the Zodiac
msItem.incipit: 1:17r Nota secundum astrologos et misael quod ie aspectus dicitur optimus quasi quidem tercius . Et est quando signum arietis respicit sagittarium post se et leonem ante se. Ille aut dicitur pessius quando aries respicit signum piscem post se et libram ante se. Primus enim aspectus Amicicie . 29 inimicicie complete
msItem.note: Full transcription.

msItem.title: On the colours of the planets
msItem.textLang: Latin, with a few words in Middle English
msItem.incipit: 1:17r Saturnus est colore pallidus
msItem.explicit: 1:17r Et nota quod planete non sintillant . id est twynkyll vel sparkyll . et per hoc potes cognoscere planeteam ab aliis stellis scillicet per colores et sintillaciones

msItem.title: Reference to a diagram on the next page
msItem.incipit: 1:17r Verte folium 21 inuenies figuram
msItem.note: A manicule in the lower margin points towards the note and on it is written in Middle English: Loke abovte.

msItem.title: Astrological diagram
msItem.rubric: 1:17v Per hanc figuram scies domos exaltaciones triplites [...] et facies planetarum ad signa
msItem.note: Circular diagram consisting of 10 concentric circles divided by 12 perpendicular lines, creating, effectively 12 rows with 8 cells each. Each row has the words Indirecte oritur or Directe oritur in their most outer cell, and, in the cell immediately below that, the name of a sign of the Zodiac.

msItem.title: The Summa in VIII Libros Physicorum Aristotelis (fragment of Book II)
msItem.author: Robert Grosseteste
msItem.textLang: Latin with marginal inscriptions in Middle English
msItem.incipit: 1:18r motus et quietis eius in quo est primo per et non secundum accidens . dicit motus et quietis . quia ea que ad locum naturaliter moventur ad . naturaliter quiescunt in loco
msItem.explicit: 1:18v sicut in corporibus generabilibus et corruptibilibus . Ad 3m [...]
msItem.note: Previously unidentified and not recorded in S. Harrison Thomson, 'The Summa in VIII Libros Physicorum of Grosseteste', Isis 22 (1934), 12-18, which identifies eight manuscripts.

Middle English inscriptions have been added by a different 15th-century hand. This concerns a manicule inscribed with the words So y do that points towards the underlined words Loke [?] Wyll and another manicule inscribed with the words be hold that points to a Latin inscription on f. 1:18r. In the outer margin of f. 1:18 is a manicule inscribed with the word Walke pointing to a banderol in red ink inscribed with the verse couplet: Marke well thys dovte . tyll Ã¾e trueth be tried ovte; and another banderol in red ink inscribed with the verse couplet [?] Arys ys well spyed / ffor here Ã¾e trueth ys tried accompanied by a manicule that points away at the text, inscribed with the word: loo. Neither of the verses are recorded in the Index of Middle Engilsh Verse.

msItem.title: Astronomical treatise (fragment)
msItem.incipit: 1:19r -ciam a terra [...]
msItem.explicit: 1:19v post tempus [...] erunt ciuitates et [...]
msItem.note: In the lower margin of f. 1:19v the word Amen is written, perhaps indicating the treatise's end.

msItem.title: Commentary on the Meteora of Aristotle (incomplete)
msItem.author: Walter Burley
msItem.incipit: 1:20r De primis igitur causis. In isto libro qui liber metheorum intitulatur . Aristoteles dat completam ordinacionem tocius philosophie naturalis
msItem.explicit: 1:30r et sit quod mulier non moriatur in partum
msItem.note: A previously unidentified copy of Burley's work; identified through comparision with a known copy in Cambridge, Trinity College, MS O.2.5.

The treatise contains a number of circular diagrams: an astrological diagram on f. 21r; a Sphere of Pythagoras on f. 21v; a diagram showing the hydrological cycle on f. 24r; a volvelle on f. 25v; and a wind diagram on f. 28v.
A manicule in the margin of f. 33r is inscribed with two words, probably Middle English, but these have not been read.

msItem.title: Reference to a diagram
msItem.rubric: 1:30r Amen. Verte folium et inuenies figuram cor[...]deatem littere
msItem.note: The diagram in question is a full-page Sphere of Pythagoras on f. 130v.

msItem.title: Meteorological diagram
msItem.incipit: 1:31r et hoc moventur circulariter per virtutem superioris motus et totum istud apparet in isto circulo presenti
msItem.note: The text is accompanied by a circular diagram that has the following text in its outer ring: In isto circulo potest hoc videre quomodo turbo mouetur circulo iiijo nubes vt patet fricienti etcaetera

msItem.title: Meteorological treatise (fragment)
msItem.incipit: 1:31r Postea inter q[...] inter ethio[...] et tiphonem
msItem.explicit: 1:31v quando nubes disparantur in paruos partes
msItem.note: Imperfect at the beginning and end. The previous item (a meteorological diagram) belongs to this treatise but material before is clearly missing. The treatise also ends imperfectly in a section on haloes and rainbows (De halo [...] et de yryde).

msItem.title: Meteorological treatise (fragment)
msItem.incipit: 1:32r -ca est depressa super poros
msItem.explicit: 1:32v contra turbem simul descendere et ideo descendit guttatim
msItem.note: In the lower margin of f. 1:32v are two manicules drawn in red ink with a flower in the same colour between them. The left manicule contains the following Middle English inscription: thys ys a praty processe hale. The right manicule contains another Middle English inscription but it has not been read.

msItem.title: Definitions of health and sickness
msItem.incipit: 1:33r Sanitas est temperamentum perficiens res naturales secundum cursum nature / Morbus est quod infert nocumentum spiritus naturali [? actioni] membrorum uero mediante

msItem.title: On the causes of a long and short life
msItem.incipit: 1:33r Medicus considerat de causis longitudinis et breuitatis vite secundum in hominibus et propter opus et non propter scire sed naturalis considerat de istis causis in omnibus vmentibus non propter opus sed propter scire
msItem.note: Full transcription.

msItem.title: Uroscopic diagram of twenty colours of urine (uroscopy wheel)
msItem.rubric: 1:33r Tabula de iudiciis vrinarum per colores
msItem.note: The diagram features three circles. In the middle circle, there are 20 urine flasks (jordans) drawn in red ink. Although these have not been coloured, each represents a different type of urine and is connected to an explanation in the outer circle. In the inner circle are eight smaller circles with of which seven comment on shared features between sets of jordans. The eighth one, positioned at the very centre of the diagram, carries the title: Tabula de iudiciis vrinarum per colores.
Below the diagram is a manicule inscribed with text (a single word, not transcribed but possibly Middle English) that points to the inscription: Verte folium et invenies plus de ma.

msItem.title: Uroscopic treatise (fragment)
msItem.incipit: 1:34v Vrina rufa significat salutem et bonam dispositionem
msItem.explicit: 1:34v Vrina spissa et plumbea circa mediane regionem nigra paralesim significat. Vrina
msItem.note: Ends imperfectly.

msItem.title: Astronomical treatise (fragment)
msItem.incipit: 1:34r circulus . habet diuidi in 12. figurae computacio debet esse sed motum lune in epicyclo incipiendo videm computacionem ab ange versus occidentem
msItem.explicit: 1:36v quando centrum epicycli est in auge

supportDesc.support: Parchment (disposition unestablished) leaves; but with one paper leaf (f. 1:18). This leaf is folded in octavo. Three-lobed leaf .

collation.note: The collation below is based on what can be gleaned from the manuscript's current physical structure. This collation, however, does not represent the the manuscript's orginal and intended structure, since the leaves in this part, as M.R. James put it, are much disordered (James (1902), p. 360). Although James has catalogued ff. 1:1-1:36 as a single part, this treatment can be questioned. While the materials in Quire 2 probably always belonged together, Quire 1 may consist of materials from two distinct parts. Whereas the text on the innermost bifolium of Quire 1 (ff. 1:7-1:8) partly concern scientific materials and was copied by a hand that also features in Quire 2, the remaining folios of Quire 1 (ff. 1:2-1:6 and ff. 1:9-1:12) contain texts on ars dictaminis, history, and biblical interpretation, in hands that differ significantly from those found in Quire 2. Consequently, the innermost bifolium of Quire 1 - together with f. 1:1 which contains an astronomical diagram - and Quire 2 may constitute one separate part, and the remaining leaves of Quire 1 (ff. 1:2-1:6 and ff. 1:9-1:12) another part. However, the materials in Quire 1 and Quire 2 could also originate from the same manuscript: in that case, ff. 1:1, 1:7-1:8, and Quire 2 represent the original core of a scientific manuscript, and the materials on ff. 1:2-1:6 and ff. 1:9-1:12 additions that were made either on blank leaves or an added quire. For this reason and practical considerations - presenting the materials in Quire 1 and 2 as two separate parts would result in a complicated overview of the manuscript's present structure - it has been decided to retain M.R. James's treatment of the manuscript's first part in this catalogue record.

list.item: Quire 112+1-1 (ff. 1:1-1:12: 1 leaf added before 1st leaf, 12th leaf missing)
Quire 220+2 (ff. 1:13-1:36: a bifolium inserted between the 10th and 11th leaves)

signatures.p: Cropped leaf signatures (a) visible in the lower outer corners of f. 13r and f. 14r.

catchwords.seg: Catchwords (underlined with red ink) written in the lower inner corners of a few leaves, perhaps originally coinciding with the final versos of quires.

condition.p: The lower margin of f. 35 has been cut out.

layout.p:
1:7r-1:8v and 1:13-1:36
85-95 70
Ruled in leadpoint, frame only. Single columns. 30-34 lines to the page, written above top line.

1:2r-1:6v and 1:9r-1:12v
90-95 70-75
Frames ruled in leadpoint (vertical lines only). Single columns. 25-27 lines to the page.

handNote.p: Folios 1:1r-1:6v were copied by a single hand writing in a cursive script with both anglicana and secretary.
Folios 1:7r, and 1:13r-1:36v were copied by a few very similar hands writing in a neat script with both anglicana and secretary features.
Folios 1:9v-1:10r were copied by a single hand writing in a secretary script.
Folios 1:10v-1:11r were copied by a single hand writing in a cursive script with both anglicana and secretary features.
Folios 1:11v-1:12r were copied by a single hand writing in a cursive script with both anglicana and secretary features.

decoNote.p: Manicules in brown and red ink with inscriptions in Middle English (see ff. 1:17r, 1:18r, 1:18v, 1:23r, 1:30r, 1:32v).

One full-page volvelle on f. 1:25v. This wheel chart consists of three paper disks of varying sizes that have been placed on top of each other and are held together with a small disk of parchment that has been sewn to the page with blue thread (see f. 1:25r).

Circular astronomical, metereological, prognostic and uroscopic diagrams in brown and red ink on ff. 1:1r (full page); 1:7v (inserted into text); 1:21r (half page); 1:21v (half page); 1:24r (inserted into text); 1:28v (nearly full page); 1:30v (full page); 1:31r (half page); 1:33r (full page).

One large (4 lines) puzzle initial in blue and red ink with penwork decoration in red ink inside the letter a J-border in blue and red ink in the inner margin, and pen-flourishing in red ink extending into the lower margin, on f. 1:20r.
Large (2-3 lines) blue initials with penwork decoration in red ink inside the letter and pen-flourishing in red ink extending into the inner margins.
Small (1 line) plain initials in red ink on ff. 1:8r-1:8v.
Ascenders on the first lines of pages higlighted in red ink.
Regular initials in dark ink highlighted with red ink.

origin.p: Possibly with additions made during the 15th century (ff. 2:2r-2:6v, 2:9v-2:12v) [see Collation for further discussion].

provenance.p: John ?Welbek [?Welbot / Wolbot] (fl. 16th century) ? Welbek [? Welbot / Wolbot], John, fl. 16th century: may have owned or accessed this part of the manuscript, or perhaps only ff. 1:2r-1:6v, 1:9r-1:12v (see Collation for further discussion). His name is inscribed in the lower margin of f. 1:11r in a faint light brown ink that is difficult to read.

msItem.title: Motto
msItem.incipit: 2:[i] recto Ora pro lige rege grege
msItem.note: Added in the (?) 16th-century by a scribe working in a humanistic cursive hand.

msItem.title: Collection of 145 medical and household recipes
Medical recipe for the ague or other stomach ailments
msItem.rubric: 2:36v ffor the ago or any other dyssecys yn the stomake
msItem.note: Added by a different hand in the late 15th or early 16th century.

msItem.title: Treatise on the four elements, humours, and qualities and their interrelationships, and on prognosis of diease by urine colour
msItem.rubric: 2:37r Here ffolloweth a schort tretys to know the .iiij. complexions and to dyscerne vryvns off men bi colors and other contentes where theyre infirmytes be and where \off/ theyre sekenes comyth
msItem.incipit: 2:37r [sic] ffrust is it to know that Ã¾er be .iiij. elementes Ã¾at is to white eyre ffyre water and erth ryght so lyke to this .iiij. elementes there be .iiij. humers blod color ffleme and malyncole and there be .iiij. humers blod color ffleme and malyncole and there be .iiij. qualites answeryng them Ã¾at is hete drye cold and moystynes and the sayd .iij. humers and qualites answeryth
msItem.explicit: 2:46r Vryne Ã¾at is redde betokeneth wynd and peyne in the ryght syde
msItem.note: The treatise contains simple drawings of urine flasks in black or red ink. Each represents a different type of urine (although the contents of the flasks are not coloured) and is accompanied by an explanatory text.

Tavormina (2014) identifies ff. 2:45r-2:46r as a segment of The Dome of Uryne Compendium [no. 2.5b]); 31 (identifies ff. 2:39v-2:42v as an incomplete text on the twenty colours of urine conflated with Urina Rufa [no. 3.1.1c]); 33 (identifies ff. 39v-42v as an incomplete copy of Urina Rufa conflated with the twenty colours of urine [no. 3.2.3]); 35 (identifies ff. 2:43r-2:45r as a version of Cleansing of Blood [no. 3.3.3]); 42 (identifies ff. 2:45r-2:46r as the Judicium Perfectum Omnium Urinarum [no. 5.1c]); 68 (identifies ff. 37r-39v as text on complexions and discerning urine [no. 8.6]); 114 (table).

msItem.title: Glossary of plant names
msItem.incipit: 2:46v Artemesia Mogwort / Absinthyn Womoth / Apium Ache or Marche
msItem.explicit: 2:48r Marubium Hor Hownd / Mellefolium Nosseblede / Narstutium Tower kers
msItem.note: Left unfinished in the N section.

msItem.title: Three recipes for making medical syrups from flowers and herbs
msItem.note: Added in the late 15th century.

msItem.title: Draft letter
msItem.incipit: 2:49v To her louyng housband maister Robert Ydo [? Yde] beyng yn [...]ulyng geue the [? that] yn yrelond
msItem.note: Added in the 16th century.

msItem.title: Religious sentence
msItem.incipit: 2:49v To reherse the faithfull
msItem.note: Added in the 16th century.

supportDesc.support: Paper, folded in octava. Folios 2:[i] recto-2:49v: hand with clover.

p.seg: Frames ruled in blindpoint (vertical lines only). Single columns. 17-20 lines to the page.

handNote.p: The original recipe collection has been copied by a single hand working in a cursive script with both anglicana and secretary features.
The original recipe collection has been copied by a single (?) late 15th-century hand working in a cursive script with both anglicana and secretary features.
A late 15th- or early 16th-century hand has added a recipe to f. 2:36v in a cursive script with both anglicana and secretary features.

decoNote.p: Headings and sub-headings for recipes are written in red ink.
Plain initials in brown ink are sometimes highlighted with red ink.

origin.origDate: Second half of the 15th century or first quarter of the 16th century.

provenance.p: Henry Chapman [Chypnam, Chipnam] (fl. 1552) Chapman [Chypnam, Chipnam], Henry, fl. 1552, Barber Surgeon of Brasenose College, Oxford: his name inscribed in the lower margin of f. 2:1r in a 16th-century hand: Henry [Chipnam] barber of brasnose. His name is also inscribed in the lower margin of f. 2:49r: be me Henry Chipnam. This inscription, which has been crossed out and affected by damp or reagent, has previously not been read. However, he undoubtedly was the Henry Chapman [Chypnam, Chipnam] who is recorded in Brasenose's register as Barbitonsor (Barber) in the year 1552. See Brasenose College Register, 1509-1909 (Oxford: Blackwell, 1909), p. 16.

Henry Walmesley (fl. 1573-1591) Walmesley, Henry, fl. 1573-1591, BA, MA, and Fellow of Brasenose College, Oxford: his name inscribed on f. 2:[i] recto in a 16th-century hand: Henricus Walmesley a dw a dogon. Previously unidentified. However, given the secure identification of Henry Chapman, Barber Surgeon of Brasenose College, as an owner of this manuscript (see above), he almost certainly is the Henry Walmesely who is recorded in Brasenose's register in the year 1573. See Brasenose College Register, 1509-1909 (Oxford: Blackwell, 1909), p. 47.

John Taverner (fl. 16th century) Taverner, John, fl. 16th century: probably his erased ownership inscription on f. 2:[i] recto in a 16th-century hand: Johannes Ta[...] est possessor [...] libri. Below the name Johannes Tauernour has been written twice: once in purple and another time in brown ink. The surname Taverner is repeated on its own below in brown ink (Taverner). Unidentified.

msItem.title: Philosophical treatise on virtue
msItem.incipit: 2:50r vertue aboue bewty - The giftes of nature perishe sodenly which hath but a mornyng lyft but our vertues of our mynd render themselves [crossed out: vertuous victorious uppon age and triopheth ouer tyme
msItem.explicit: 2:56v and therfore /[...]s\ where the mother loveth and estemeth shall sonest obteine the daughter

msItem.title: Correspondence (perhaps literary)
msItem.incipit: 2:57r Fortune hath bound me so strictly to obay the excellent graces which abounde in you that whereas vntill this tyme I haue ben at fre liberty from hence forth I am becom a carfull captane in such sorte as I knowe not what enlargment [crossed out: to haue] I ought to expecte not hauing any other then it shal please your mercye to graunte me of your mere grace
msItem.explicit: 2:57v I haue whereuppon to feede my starued eare with the nourishmente of good hope of your fauoure and graces
msItem.note: Two letters, the first one is sent by a servant who claims to be in the addressee's amarous service. The second one is a reply.

msItem.title: Table of contents for Antonio de Guevara, A Looking Glasse for the Court, trans. Sir Francis Bryan and Thomas Tymme (London: William Norton, 1575)
msItem.rubric: 2:58r The loking glasse for the cort
msItem.incipit: 2:58r ffortitude consisteth in mortefying affections fo. 5. Pag. 1
msItem.explicit: 2:58v man likes best of that whervnto he is most inclined fol. eod. Pag 2
msItem.note: An English translation of Antonio de Guevara (b. c. 1481-d. 1545), Menosprecio de corte y alabanza de aldea.

msItem.title: Opening of Book 2, Chapter 2 of Antonio de Guevara, A Looking Glasse for the Court, trans. Sir Francis Bryan and Thomas Tymme (London: William Norton, 1575)
msItem.author: Antonio de Guevara
msItem.incipit: 2:59r Aristarcus the [crossed out: ph] Theban philosopher said that tyme and man [crossed out: was] is [crossed out: one] so diuers that hard it is even for the wisest to chose that to them which is good and kepe them from that which is evell for them
msItem.explicit: 2:59r that which well contenteth one, an other is not satisfyed

msItem.title: Excerpts on human nature and virtue
msItem.incipit: 2:59r The only knowledge of man to know little procedeth of the modesty of some richer vertue
msItem.explicit: 2:60r poore victuailes and small he[...] which is not in this.

msItem.title: Cease Sorrows Now
msItem.author: Thomas Weelkes (bap. 1576?, d. 1623)
msItem.rubric: 2:61r A faint farwell off a faithfull frend dispairing to live after her frendes departure
msItem.incipit: 2:61r Seace sorrow now for thow hast don the deed / Lo care hath now consvmd my carcas quit / No hepe can helpe nor helpe can stand insted / ffor dolfull death doth cutt off all delight / Yet whilst I heer the towling of the bell / Before I dye I wright this faint farwell
msItem.note: Full transcription. Previously unidentified copy of Weelkes' work. The poem is almost identical to that found in Madrigals to Three, Four, Five and Six Voyces (1597) but there are minor variations. For example, the last line appears to have been deliberately changed to adapt the poem to a literary-manuscript context: while the Madrigal version has: before I dye, Ile sing my faint farewell, the version in this manuscript gives: Before I dye I wright this faint farwell.

msItem.title: Farewell Fancy (provisional title)
msItem.author: Thomas Weelkes (bap. 1576?, d. 1623)
msItem.incipit: 2:61r ffancy farwell you wroughtst my fond delighte / Delight adue the cawre of my distresse
msItem.explicit: 2:61v ffolly farwele that I have fancyed so / And farwell fancy that first wrought my woe
msItem.note: This appears to be a previously unknown poem by Thomas Weelkes as it is not included in David Brown, Thomas Weelkes: A Biographical and Critical Study (London: Faber and Faber, 1969). Aside from the fact that the poem is attributed to a T.W., this poem fits thematically well with other works by Weelkes, for example his Farewell, my joy (1598). It is possible that this poem is a direct continuation of Cease Sorrows Now, and that both form a single work for the faithfull frend who is mentioned in the title written above the preceding poem.

msItem.title: A Farewell to the World
msItem.author: 'T.L.'
msItem.rubric: 2:61a recto A farwell to the world
msItem.incipit: 2:61a recto When as the shade of all my sorrowes past / Presents itself vnto my hedles saight
msItem.explicit: 2:62r Then will ye wishe as I all reddy doe / Ye had ben wise and thus vain world adue

msItem.title: Health regimen
msItem.author: Leonardo Fioravanti
msItem.rubric: 2:65r A difendersi dalle informita et conseruarsi in sanita remedio salutifero
msItem.incipit: 2:65r A volersi diffender dalle infirmita et conservarsi in sanita farai le infrascritte: pillule, et vsale secondo questa ricetta, et ti conseruerai sempre sano fino alla morte
msItem.explicit: 2:65v et il modo di vsarle et molto facile et senza fastidio, o trauaglio alcuno. Leonardo fiorauanti Bolognese doctor: et Caualier
msItem.note: The health regimen refers to Pope Paul III (1534-1549) and is attributed to Leonardo Fioravanti (1517-1588), physician, surgeon, and alchemist of Bologna.

msItem.title: Three recipes for making ink
msItem.incipit: 2:65r Del modo di fare l'inchiostro commune che si perscriuere
msItem.note: The first recipe is for making general ink and the two other recipes are for making red ink for writing on paper. They are entitled: Del modo di voler fare inchiostro rosso di verzino da scriuere in carta and Del modo di fare inchiostro rosso in altro modo, et facilita.

msItem.title: Medical recipe for strained or stiffened nerves
msItem.author: ?Leonardo Fioravanti
msItem.rubric: 2:66v A chi hauesse i nerui ritirati, o induriti, per qual si voglia causa e rimedio bonissimo
msItem.incipit: 2:65r Se fusse alcuna persona, che hauesse vn neruo indurito, o ritirato, per intenerirlo, et distenderlo, facia questo reimedio, cioe, Recipe radice di ebulo, libro
msItem.explicit: 2:66v Concludo, che questo sia il piu perfecto, rimedio che si possa vsare, et credo, che fusse inventione di Alfonso Ferro Napolitano, perch[e] esso teneua un licor, che faceua miracoli in Roma, il quale era questo, et non altro, perche l'ho fatto io, et era simile a quello in [crossed out: quantita] qualita, et in operatione
msItem.note: The author, perhaps Leonardo Fioravanti (see the health regimen above), concludes the recipe by identifying it as the 'miraculous' medicine that was used by Alfonso Ferro of Naples, physician to Pope Paul III (r. 1534-1549).
A marginal note in a similar hand provides an English translation for the first ingredient: Ebulum - Walwort.

msItem.title: Recipe for making sweet perfume
msItem.incipit: 2:67v Take cloves and stick them thick in an vrange, and lett thoreug drye soa longe as yf yt will be beaten to powder, then bray yt and preserue yt for an excellent sweety perfumy
msItem.note: Full transcription.

msItem.title: Account list of payments
msItem.note: The list refers to objects in gold and silver. Added in the 16th century. The text has been crossed out.

msItem.title: Account list of payments
msItem.note: Added in the 16th century. The text has been crossed out.

msItem.title: Unspecified list of books
msItem.note: The list is untitled and most entries have been crossed out.

msItem.title: List of books on loan
msItem.note: The list includes the names of borrowers: John Warton, William Marshall at m. Peckes Mr Churchmans sonne, Richarde at faireclughes, Alexander Farrington, Thomas Pynner, and Katheryne lloyd.

msItem.title: List of books borrowed from Thomas Crevises
msItem.rubric: 2:75r A not of the bookes I haue of Thomas Crevises [? Trevises]

msItem.title: List of books borrowed from and loaned to H. Chillesters
List of books borrowed from Henry Chillesters
msItem.rubric: 2:75r A not of the bookes I haue of Thomas Crevises
msItem.note: The final entry is Mr Hollyband - A french Dictionary. It is not entirely clear whether this is a new list or whether it refers to a publication. In any case, the Mr Hollyband in question almost certainly is Claudius Hollyband (1564-1594), a French Huguenot refugee who came to London about 1564 and published his A Dictionarie French and english there.

msItem.title: Note on payments for books, dated August 1589
msItem.incipit: 2:76v Lent one in Mr watersons shop at his request a Spa [sic: ? Spanish] Dictionar - viijs [...]
msItem.note: The note may refer to the shop of the London stationer Simon Waterson (fl. 1583-1635) at the Crown in St Paul's Churchyard.

msItem.title: List of books owned, dated 29 September 1582
msItem.rubric: 2:77r A note of my bookes 29 Septembris 1582
msItem.note: The list is divided into four sections for: Latin books (ff. 2:77r-2:77a verso), English books (ff. 2:78r-2:79v), Law books (ff. 2:80r-2:80v), and French books (ff. 2:81r-2:81v). Each sub-list is dated to 29 September 1582.

supportDesc.support: Paper, folded in octavo. Folios 2:50-2:81: Unidentified.

p.seg: No ruling. Single columns. c. 25-c. 35 lines to the page.

handNote.p: Folios 2:50r-2:62r were copied by late 16th-century or early 17th-century cursive hand with both anglicana and secretary features.
Folios 2:65r-2:67r were copied by a late 16th-century or early 17th-century Italic script.
Folios 2:67v, 2:69v, and 2:71r were copied by late 16th-century or early 17th-century cursive hands with both anglicana and secretary features.
Folios 2:72r-2:81v were copied by different late 16th-century (? and early 17th-century) hands, indlucing both cursive script with anglicana and secretary features and Italic script.

decoNote.p: This part of the manuscript does not contain any significant forms of decoration.

origin.origDate: Last quarter of the 16th century and/or first quarter of the 17th century.

msIdentifier.idno: Cambridge, Trinity College, MS R.14.39, ff. 2:82-2:91

msItem.title: Collection of medical recipes
msItem.note: Almost completely written in Latin except for a rubric on f. 2:84r: for starke and stiffe lymmes.

msItem.title: Two medical recipes
msItem.note: Written in plummet.

supportDesc.support: Paper, folded in ?octavo; but no watermark visible.

p.seg: No ruling. Single columns. 14-18 lines to the page.

handNote.p: Copied by a single 16th-century hand working in a script with both anglicana and secretary features.

decoNote.p: This part of the manuscript does not contain any significant forms of decoration.

msItem.title: Collection of medical and culinary recipes
msItem.note: The collection contains a version of Dr Stevens water on f. 2:93r. For other copies, see: The collection includes culinary recipes: To make white marmelet, for quindinake, Diet bred, Calib preparid, Cinamon et ginger on ff. 2:93r-2:93v; A pomander contra pestem on f. 2:94r.

Two recipes, one on f. 2:101r and another on f. 2:103r, are attributed to a Mr Lilas [unidentified]. Two recipes, one on f. 2:101v and f. 2:102r, are attributed to a Docter langhton. The latter may be Christopher Langton (1521â1578), physician and Fellow of King's College, Cambridge. One recipe on f. 2:102v is attributed to a Dr grimston. He may have been Thomas Grimston (d. 1608), doctor of medicine at Cambridge (see W. M. Palmer, Cambridgeshire Doctors in the Olden Time, 1466-1827, The Cambridge Antiquarian Society's Communications, 15 (1911), 200-279 (p. 264)).

msItem.title: List of payments
msItem.incipit: 2:110r Item for xij shipe scilicet xijs
msItem.explicit: 2:110r Item for on shipe - vjs
msItem.note: The page features the heading for a medical recipes (ffor malincolye) that was never added.

msItem.title: List of wages
msItem.incipit: 2:135v Item for 4 dayes wrke xij [...]
msItem.explicit: 2:135v Item for ton daye work \at worke/ 7d
msItem.note: The list specifies a payment of 9 d for work carried out on 9 April (Easter).

msItem.title: List of wages
msItem.incipit: 2:136r Item for xij shipe scilicet xijs [5] 1 d
msItem.explicit: 2:136r Item for xx shipe - [7] l xs

msItem.title: Alphabetical index to medical recipes
msItem.note: Written in an italic script by a later, (?)17th-century hand, referring to the medical recipes in this part.

msItem.title: Collection of medical recipes
msItem.note: Two recipes, one on f. 2:161r and another on f. 2:166v, are attributed to a certain Mr Butler. The latter may be William Butler (1535â1618), Fellow of Clare College, Cambridge, and physician. Another recipe on f. 2:174v is attributed to a certain Mr Turner; perhaps referring to William Turner (1509/10âJuly 1568), physician and natural historian.

msItem.title: List of payments
msItem.incipit: 2:166v Item for trie part of [...]
msItem.explicit: 2:166v Item for heay [...]
msItem.note: The text has become much faded or has been partially erased.

msItem.title: List of payments
msItem.incipit: 2:164v Iti for xx webbers 7 [...]
msItem.explicit: 2:164v Iti for [d] j lames xxs vjs
msItem.note: The list ends with a sum of all payments and the note the wile be at hola[r] donne.

msItem.title: Prayer
msItem.incipit: 2:164v O God ont hige thow me defend from the sotle sort of thos that frenship to me doth dol[es]
msItem.note: Full transcription.

supportDesc.support: Paper, folded in octavo; but no watermark visible.

list.item: The collation for ff. 92-166 has not been established.

p.seg: No ruling. Single columns. lines to the page. c. 18-c. 32 lines to the page.

handNote.p: Copied by a (?) single 16th-century hand working in a cursive script with both anglicana and secretary features.

decoNote.p: This part of the manuscript does not contain any significant forms of decoration.

msIdentifier.idno: Cambridge, Trinity College, MS R.14.39, ff. 2:175-2:196

msItem.title: Medical recipe
msItem.note: Immediately below the recipe is written in a similar script the following inscription: Thomas [?]brysdon off the set

msItem.title: Poem
msItem.incipit: 2:175r I deserve so I desyer this lovers oft make ther request / yf yraunt yt be that I requier what manye prevaile syns at the least
msItem.note: Full transcription.

msItem.title: Medical recipe for an unstated purpose
msItem.incipit: 2:175v put into the bolle with a pessarie: Knotgrasse / Lysimachus / Nightshad
msItem.note: Full transcription.

msItem.title: Table of herbs for medical ailments
msItem.note: Three columns with the headings: all issves, inordinat termes, and all flixes of the belly.

msItem.title: Table of contents for medical texts in this part
msItem.incipit: 2:179r Tractatus de medecinis - 1
msItem.explicit: 2:179r Oleum tartari - 18

msItem.title: Collection of medical recipes
msItem.rubric: 2:180r Tractatus de medicinis ad dispositionem quinte essencie
msItem.incipit: 2:180r In hoc parte describentur omnia simplicia que conueniunt ad intencionem nostre diuine quinte essencie Aque uite pro ut in suo speciali tractatu continetur

supportDesc.support: Paper, folded in octavo. Folios 2:175r-2:196: ? Initial 'I' or 'L' ? Hand.
supportDesc.condition: A recangular piece of paper has been cut out of the outer lower half of f. 179.

p.seg: No ruling. Single columns except for ff. which has two columns. 16-20 lines to the page,

handNote.p: The texts on f. 2:175r were copied by 16th-century cursive hands with secretary and anglicana features.
Folios 2:177v-2:196v were copied by a single hand writing in a 16th-century humanistic cursive script.

decoNote.p: Folios 2:177v-2:178r contain drawings of vessels in brown ink that are placed on furnaces or cauldrons and heated by fires in red ink. Accompanying Latin labels identify these objects.

change.persName: Dr Clarck Drieshen, Project Cataloguer in Curious Cures in Cambridge Libraries, Cambridge University Library
